Award.AwardTitle: Planning Project: Improving Retention and the Quality of STEM Education and Research at Oakwood University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program provides support for projects to design, implement, and assess strategies that can lead to comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. This two-year planning project at Oakwood College seeks to increase the number of women and under-represented minorities in STEM by developing a program that will recruit, retain and graduate students in STEM disciplines. Transforming the institutional context to actively engage students in their learning and develop skills for them to succeed academically is a primary focus.

The overall project goal is to increase the number of well-prepared, competitively trained minority STEM graduate who pursue graduate studies or enter the STEM workforce. Traditional lecture based and teacher-centered instructional strategies have been shown to not effectively motivate or retain students' interest in STEM disciplines. Oakwood College will incorporate evidence based pedagogies, such as Student Centered/Active Learning, Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL) and Problem Based Learning, in gatekeeper courses to improve student learning and first-year retention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oakwood University, through a HBCU-UP program Planning Grant, plan to improve student recruitment and retention, redesign curriculum in science and mathematics, and strengthen the instructional, training and research infrastructure as well as strengthen the science and mathematics preparation of incoming students. We will recruit faculty from freshman level classes and assist them in implementing novel instructional approaches to learning in their courses. The teaching strategy goals/objectives were to provide an engagement strategy to faculty that can help students, inside and outside of the classroom, improve their learning and academic success in the classroom. The overall goal was to recruit STEM students to: 1) enrich their academic experience, 2) increase interest in research and matriculate into graduate programs, and 3) increase the competitiveness for students who plan to apply to graduate school or enter the STEM workforce. The HBCU-UP program at Oakwood University was structured to achieve these goals by recruiting, advising, preparing, conducting research, nurturing students and working with faculty to conduct research and explore different approaches to teaching and student focus learning.

The program utilized collaborative learning, supplemental instruction, advising, workshops and seminars, and student-to-student mentoring to ensure success of the program. Faculty re-designed traditional gate-keeper courses in order to increase retention of students. These courses, General Biology, College Algebra, pre-Calculus and General Chemistry will incorporate changes in instructional strategies, and will benefit from an enhanced view of the relationship of the course materials with those of other discipline. The project is intended to supplement in-class instruction with increased undergraduate student research, seminars and workshops.

Over the two year period 35 students were selected and paired with research faculty to be advised, engaged in research and mentored. They participated in workshops to build skills essential for graduate school and being a research scientist. Students participated and presented their research at local, regional and national meetings. These students received peer-research mentorship from other STEM students. HBCU-UP students were required to become certified in Research Conduct, Laboratory Safety, and Research Study and Design. Additional certifications were completed based on the student’s specific area of research.  Other certifications that were completed through CITI Certifications were: Biomedical Responsible Conduct in Research, Biosafety, Research Study Design, Nanotechnology, Human Gene Transfer and Personal Protective Equipment.  Several workshops and seminars were held during the school year on topics such as applying to graduate school, writing a personal statement, research opportunities, research projects and how to apply to graduate school. Students presented at several National and regional conferences.    Five students and three faculty members attended the: Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), November 13-16, Anaheim, CA. Three students received Travel Grants. Five students and One Faculty Member attended the Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference, February 2020, Washington D.C.  Four students received Travel Grants.  One won second place. Three students made presentations at the Southeastern Branch of American Society of Microbiology (SEB-ASM)-February 2020, Huntsville AL.

During the academic year, over 100 students including HBCU-UP students were involved with service-learning activities. Oakwood University students, faculty and staff participated in Agape Day on September 26, 2019. STEM faculty and students went to several public schools to work with teachers on hands on laboratory experiments related to their grade level and curriculum. Chemistry Night was held on October 28, 2019, in in conjunction with the local Mensa Chapter to introduce children to science.  Children of all ages were accompanied by a parent or guardian visited the Chemistry Department to conduct hands on experiments with the parents or guardian.  STEM majors were available to assist and explain the experiments. Science Day was held on February 24, 2020 when we had over 450 Public School and Homeschool students participating.  Teachers are invited to bring their classes to visit a HBCU and conduct fun experiments and observe demonstrations.

During the School year students and faculty assist a local Elementary School teachers and students fulfill their science requirements by providing science experiments and assistance with STEM instruction.
